In general, the memory for an agent is something that we provide via context in the prompt passed to LLM that helps the agent to better plan and react given past interactions or data not immediately available.

It is useful to group https://t.co/dzPPW3wWPm
note_tweet_text:
AI Agents 101: ùóîùóú ùóîùó¥ùó≤ùóªùòÅ ùó†ùó≤ùó∫ùóºùóøùòÜ.

In general, the memory for an agent is something that we provide via context in the prompt passed to LLM that helps the agent to better plan and react given past interactions or data not immediately available.

It is useful to group the memory into four types:

ùü≠. Episodic - This type of memory contains past interactions and actions performed by the agent. After an action is taken, the application controlling the agent would store the action in some kind of persistent storage so that it can be retrieved later if needed. A good example would be using a vector Database to store semantic meaning of the interactions.

ùüÆ. Semantic - Any external information that is available to the agent and any knowledge the agent should have about itself. You can think of this as a context similar to one used in RAG applications. It can be internal knowledge only available to the agent or a grounding context to isolate part of the internet scale data for more accurate answers.

ùüØ. Procedural - This is systemic information like the structure of the System Prompt, available tools, guardrails etc. It will usually be stored in Git, Prompt and Tool Registries.

ùü∞. Occasionally, the agent application would pull information from long-term memory and store it locally if it is needed for the task at hand.

ùü±. All of the information pulled together from the long-term or stored in local memory is called short-term or working memory. Compiling all of it into a prompt will produce the prompt to be passed to the LLM and it will provide further actions to be taken by the system.

We usually label 1. - 3. as Long-Term memory and 5. as Short-Term memory.

A visual explanation of potential implementation details üëá

And that is it! The rest is all about how you architect the topology of your Agentic Systems. 

What do you think about memory in AI Agents?

#LLM #AI #MachineLearning

name: Kevin Kern
full_text:
If ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is like jamming on a guitar, Sommelier Coding is like conducting an orchestra.

When you work alone, you can "vibe" through the process. But in a team, you can't expect that everyone follows your vision and long term goals.

Recently I found myself questioning https://t.co/oOcfQmaJRv
note_tweet_text:
If ‚Äúvibe coding‚Äù is like jamming on a guitar, Sommelier Coding is like conducting an orchestra.

When you work alone, you can "vibe" through the process. But in a team, you can't expect that everyone follows your vision and long term goals.

Recently I found myself questioning the entire planning routine. Even though I already use AI to generate specs, it still takes effort to prepare them for sprints, organizing them into tickets e.g.

And then we have this situation where the PM is generating the specs and user stories with AI. And the devs are generating a summary of the Stories and the Code with AI. You get it.

Code Sommelier:
- Act as Product Manager + Software Architect + "Foreman" Dev
- Mainly uses Deep Research + Pro Models to generate "Codestories"
- Leads the Team and give direction

Dev:
- Picking a CodeStory from the Roadmap
- Puts the building blocks together with AI
- Does Quality Checks and Tests

The Concept:
The main idea is to generate code snippets that fit seamlessly into the overall architecture, since the LLM has a full understanding of it.

Additionally, through the research process, you‚Äôve already identified and preselected a suitable tech stack.

Just like a sommelier selecting the perfect wine for each course.

Example:
Defining an ERD Diagram is unnecessary when devs can get the full Drizzle schema in one run. If someone needs an explanation then reverse it to a diagram.

- Traditional Development: Thorough and methodical, but can drown you in specs, user stories, and sprint rituals. Good for clarity, slower to deliver.

- Vibe Coding: Fast and freeform. Let the AI build everything on the fly, but structure and consistency often suffer. Fine for tiny side projects, risky for bigger team efforts.

- Sommelier Coding: Balances speed and oversight. Think of it like a sommelier selecting the perfect wine for each course - curating the best fit while giving everyone a taste of the outcome. You‚Äôre still making careful choices, but without forcing everyone to read an encyclopedia of wines beforehand.

note_tweet_text:
Everyone is building RAG applications, but nobody is talking about the data these systems use.

You are delusional if you think clients will have their data sitting in a folder waiting for you to process it.

Data is everywhere: in Google Drive, Dropbox, S3, Gmail, Slack, you name it.

And, of course, no sane developer wants to build connections to every one of these systems. This would be suicide.

I'm working with Ragie, and they released Ragie Connect to solve this problem.

First, their RAG system is top-notch (they have published how they do on several RAG benchmarks), and with Connect, they made it very simple to integrate client data without having to write any code.

(Well, in reality, you still have to write a few lines, but it's minimal.)

Instead of developing one-off integrations for Drive, Dropbox, etc, you can use Connect to integrate with all of them and let Ragie handle authentication, authorization, and automatic data synchronization.

This is a huge time saver!

full_text:

If you've ever felt overwhelmed by the technical complexity of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) or thought, ‚ÄúWhere do I even begin?‚Äù, this https://t.co/F01NSo0GMN
note_tweet_text:
ü•áüèÜ This is the Most Complete Paper on Agentic RAG I've Read: Now Even Better with 10 New Updates ‚Äì An Absolute Zero-to-Hero Journey!

If you've ever felt overwhelmed by the technical complexity of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) or thought, ‚ÄúWhere do I even begin?‚Äù, this paper is your ultimate guide.

Let‚Äôs explore it together:

„Äã What is RAG?

‚ú∏ Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) integrates LLMs with real-time data sources, providing accurate and contextually enriched responses. While effective, traditional RAG systems are static and limited to predefined workflows.

„Äã Evolution of RAG Systems

‚ú∏ Na√Øve RAG: Relies on keyword-based retrieval, leading to fragmented outputs and scalability issues.

‚ú∏ Advanced RAG: Incorporates semantic retrieval techniques like Dense Passage Retrieval (DPR) and neural re-ranking for improved precision.

‚ú∏ Modular RAG: Introduces hybrid retrieval strategies, APIs, and composable pipelines for task-specific optimization.

‚ú∏ Graph RAG: Enhances multi-hop reasoning using graph-based structures but suffers from scalability challenges.

‚ú∏ Agentic RAG: Surpasses these by introducing autonomous decision-making, iterative refinement, and real-time workflow optimization.

„Äã What is Agentic RAG?

‚ú∏ Agentic RAG builds on this by embedding autonomous agents into the RAG pipeline. These agents dynamically refine context, optimize retrieval strategies, and adapt in real time to the complexity of queries, making them ideal for sophisticated, multi-step tasks.

„Äã Core Agentic Patterns

‚ú∏ Reflection: Enables agents to critique and refine outputs iteratively, boosting accuracy.

‚ú∏ Planning: Decomposes complex tasks into manageable subtasks, ensuring flexibility in execution.

‚ú∏ Tool Use: Integrates external resources, like APIs or databases, to enhance generative outputs.

‚ú∏ Multi-Agent Collaboration: Specialized agents collaborate to handle complex workflows efficiently.

„Äã Benefits of Agentic RAG

‚ú∏ Dynamic Adaptability: Adjusts workflows in real time based on task requirements.

‚ú∏ Enhanced Contextual Understanding: Iteratively refines outputs for higher relevance and accuracy.

‚ú∏ Scalability and Flexibility: Handles multi-domain queries with seamless integration of tools and data.

‚ú∏ Workflow Optimization: Reduces latency, ensuring efficiency even in high-demand scenarios.

„Äã --New-- Agentic Workflow Patterns

‚ú∏ Prompt Chaining: Breaks tasks into multiple steps

‚ú∏ Routing: Directs queries to specialized processes

‚ú∏ Parallelization: Runs processes simultaneously

‚ú∏ Orchestrator-Worker Model: Assigns subtasks to agents

‚ú∏ Evaluator-Optimizer Loop: Iteratively refines responses

note_tweet_text:
Up to 30% of the weight lost while dieting can come from lean muscle mass‚Äîbut the right training and nutrition can help you preserve muscle, which is key for metabolic health and reducing the risk of sarcopenia.

You can lose fat and gain muscle at the same time‚Äîa process called body recomposition‚Äîif you train and eat strategically.

The most important factor is resistance training. Lifting heavy 2‚Äì3 times per week is essential for maintaining and building muscle while losing fat. Without it, muscle mass inevitably declines. 

Nutrition also plays a major role. Eating in a slight calorie deficit‚Äîaround 10‚Äì20% below maintenance‚Äîallows for steady fat loss without sacrificing muscle, energy levels, or training performance.

Protein intake is another key priority. Research shows that consuming 1.8 to 2.2 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight per day is optimal for muscle retention and growth during a calorie deficit, and going even higher may provide additional benefits.

Beyond training and nutrition, recovery is just as crucial. Adequate sleep, stress management, and tracking progress help ensure you‚Äôre making real, sustainable changes. Get this right and you have a powerful strategy to build muscle and lose fat.

If you want to learn more about optimizing body recomposition, improving VO2 max, and enhancing brain health, tune into the latest episode of the FoundMyFitness podcast, where @b_holmer and I break it all down with insights from top experts.

name: Andy Galpin, PhD
full_text:
Want to speed up your metabolism?

Here's what science says about boosting your metabolism. There are numerous evidence-based ways that actually work! But‚Ä¶ most of what you've heard is wrong. So, let‚Äôs clear up the confusion on what‚Äôs bogus, what‚Äôs real, and what ‚Äòspeeding up
note_tweet_text:
Want to speed up your metabolism?

Here's what science says about boosting your metabolism. There are numerous evidence-based ways that actually work! But‚Ä¶ most of what you've heard is wrong. So, let‚Äôs clear up the confusion on what‚Äôs bogus, what‚Äôs real, and what ‚Äòspeeding up your metabolism‚Äô really means - and what it does not!

A deep dive into the research with surprising findings:

First: You can't actually "speed up" your metabolism. That's like saying you can make your car drive faster when it's parked.

What you can do is influence how many "miles" your metabolism drives each day.

Here's how it works:

Your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE) has 4 components:

1. Exercise Activity (EAT): 0-30% of calories
2. Non-Exercise Activity (NEAT): 5-30%
3. Thermal Effect of Food (TEF): 8-15%
4. Resting Metabolic Rate (RMR): 40-80%

The research shows there are both acute (temporary; minutes to hours) and chronic (long-term; days to weeks or months) ways to influence these components. Most of the nonsense in this topic comes from people making claims about things that enhance ‚Äòmetabolic rate‚Äô acutely - which as you‚Äôll see, is actually quite easy to do. But this is very deceiving because acute increase often means very little in the long-term, especially for outcomes like fat loss, and they aren‚Äôt necessarily increasing your metabolism in the way you think (they ramp up RMR, for a few minutes, but then it goes right back down to normal, or even below baseline). So, it‚Äôs quite easy to deceive with legitimate science here.

That said, let's look at what actually works for acute changes, and by how much:

Acute Boosters:

1. Spicy foods (peppers, ginger, chilis, etc.)

- Increases RMR by 3-5%
- Effect lasts 1-2 hours
- Often through capsaicin in chili peppers

2. Cold exposure

- Lowering room temp by few degrees
- Can lead to significant fat loss over time

3. Caffeine

- Increases RMR by 3-11%
- Lasts 1-3 hours
- Also reduces appetite

4. Green tea

- 4-5% RMR increase
- Similar duration to caffeine
- Compounds with caffeine for better results

But here's what's really interesting: The chronic (long-term) changes are what really matter for sustainable results.

Research shows 4 key factors for long-term metabolic enhancement:

1. Quality Sleep

- Poor sleep reduces RMR
- Increases hunger hormones
- Can reduce fat loss by 55%
- Affects muscle preservation

2. Fish Oil (3g/day)

- 14% increase in RMR
- 19% increase in fat oxidation
- 4% increase in lean mass over 12 weeks

3. Muscle Mass

- Each pound burns 6-10 extra calories daily
- Primary factor in age-related metabolic decline
- Explains up to 80% of RMR variance

4. Exercise

- Strength training: +100 cal/day RMR
- Cardio: +50-60 cal/day RMR
- Combined: +75 cal/day RMR

The most effective approach? Combining multiple strategies:

- 200 cal from additional exercise
- Fish oil + green tea (+25-50 cal)
- Protein increase (+45 cal from TEF)
- 15-min daily walk (+100 cal)
- Small calorie reduction (-80 cal)

This approach works because it:

- Doesn't crash your metabolism
- Preserves muscle mass
- Avoids adaptive thermogenesis
- Creates sustainable habits

The key isn't finding one magic solution - it's stacking small, evidence-based changes.

Remember: Your metabolism isn't "fast" or "slow."

It's responding to your daily choices in sleep, nutrition, activity, and muscle mass.

Focus on these factors consistently, and you'll create lasting metabolic health.

note_tweet_text:
Our AI hedge fund can now short stocks.

Previously, it could only go long.

It can now take 5 actions:
1 ‚Ä¢ buy
2 ‚Ä¢ sell
3 ‚Ä¢ short
4 ‚Ä¢ cover
5 ‚Ä¢ hold

This lets the hedge fund go long when it is bullish and short when it is bearish.

The agents in the hedge fund create bullish / bearish / neutral signals.

These signals are then given to the portfolio manager.

It is up to the portfolio manager to decide whether to go long / short / hold.

An overview of the 5 actions:

1. Buy is a standard long position.

2. Sell lets our hedge fund close a long position.

3. Short is a short position, with a margin requirement of 50%.

4. Cover lets our hedge fund cover a short position.

5. Hold is used when the hedge fund should not take any action.

note_tweet_text:
How I'm building my personal "Cursor for Learning" with @lovable_dev  (and no coding experience or ML background)

1) Brainstormed about my Notion, Miro & Obsidian frustrations with o1 pro (which is really good at bringing structure in disparate ideas)

2) Ask o1 to create a PRD based on the structured outcome of this brainstorm

3) Copy-paste PRD in @lovable_dev  and start building

4) Stuck on an issue Lovable can't solve? Simply clone your repo from Github, open it in @cursor_ai,  share your issue with Deepseek r1 or o1 and ask it to come up with a step-by-step solution

5) If the solution works, either update your code on your main Github manually or simply share the step-by-step solution inside Lovable

Important nuance: I'm not trying to build a Notion + Miro + Obsidian Frankenstein monster, but rather a knowledge management & learning tool that combines the features that I need.

Currently trying to convert all my notes, chat logs and resources into embeddings so the LLMs can "learn" from them and give me new insights.

I would LOVE to have a ChatGPT Tasks like feature that gives me regular insights "Hey, I noticed you've been reading a lot about SAEs, maybe this insight might interest you?" (I'd like the orb in the top left corner to glow when it has found a new insight)

In fact, I built this tool because I'm currently deep-diving into the intersection of AI & Design, and existing tools weren't doing exactly what I wanted.

With Lovable I can add new features in real-time.

And not just the basic features like a login page or a chatbot, but also the more profound stuff. 

I'm literally obsessed with the work and writings of people like @JungleSilicon, @Wattenberger, @thesephist , ... and what's crazy is that I can immediately experiment with and integrate their mind-blowing insights into my own work

Even though most these advanced features fail most of the time, each experiment and philosophical discussion with o1, Claude, or R1 deepens my understanding and expands my intuition about AI & Design.

note_tweet_text:
I've been building a real-world AI hedge fund.

Everything is open source and free to run.

You can mix-and-match multiple agents:
1 - technical agent
2 ‚Ä¢ valuation agent
3 ‚Ä¢ sentiment agent
4 ‚Ä¢ fundamentals agent
5 ‚Ä¢ warren buffett agent

The hedge fund is powered by @LangChainAI

LangGraph made it very easy to build this project.

No coding experience is required to run it.

One major update is that the hedge fund can analyze multiple tickers at once.

Here is an overview of each agent:

1. Technical Agent: calculates technical signals like RSI, MACD, etc.

2. Valuation Agent: runs a DCF to calculate intrinsic value

3. Sentiment Agent: uses insider trades and market news to calculate sentiment

4. Fundamentals Agent: determines the strength and quality of a company

5. Warren Buffett Agent: uses Mr. Buffett's principles to analyze a company

The output of each agent is passed to a risk manager agent who does position sizing.

Finally, all signals are given to a portfolio manager agent for the final trading decision.

This project is barely scratching the surface of what is possible.

Vision is to add more agents and finetune the LLMs that the agents use.

Always open to more suggestions.

Build human-like memory for your Agents!

Every agentic and RAG system struggles with real-time knowledge updates and fast data retrieval.

Zep AI solves these issues with its continuously learning and temporally-aware Knowledge Graph‚Äîthink of it as human memory for AI Agents. https://t.co/QZIshV1ncR
note_tweet_text:
Build human-like memory for your Agents!

Every agentic and RAG system struggles with real-time knowledge updates and fast data retrieval.

Zep AI solves these issues with its continuously learning and temporally-aware Knowledge Graph‚Äîthink of it as human memory for AI Agents.

Like humans, Zep organizes an Agent's memories into episodes, extracts entities and their relationships from these episodes, and stores them in a knowledge graph:

(refer the image below as you read)

1Ô∏è‚É£ Episode Subgraph: Captures raw data with timestamps, retaining every detail for easy historical lookup.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Semantic Entity Subgraph: Extracts entities (e.g., ‚ÄúAlice,‚Äù ‚ÄúGoogle‚Äù) and facts (‚ÄúAlice works at Google‚Äù). Everything is versioned, so outdated info gets replaced.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Community Subgraph: Groups related entities into clusters, with summaries for faster retrieval.

Zep delivers up to 18.5% higher accuracy with 90% lower latency when compared to tools like MemGPT.

It's fully open-source. I've shared a detailed paper with more information and their GitHub repository in next tweet!
